title: Elements missing in quarkus-config-javadoc.yaml for types nested more deeply than 1 level
body:
We have a config property `quarkus.cxf.client."client-name".otel.enabled` in Quarkus CXF modelled as follows:

https://github.com/quarkiverse/quarkus-cxf/tree/e163e2c5a5411e1c0048c58de651ff39b8e1fbcd/extensions/integration-tracing-opentelemetry/runtime/src/main/java/io/quarkiverse/cxf/opentelemetry/CxfOpenTelemetryConfig.java#L20-L81

Actual: After the compilation with the new `quarkus-extension-processor`, the `quarkus-config-javadoc.yaml` looks as follows:

```
---
extension:
  groupId: "io.quarkiverse.cxf"
  artifactId: "quarkus-cxf-integration-tracing-opentelemetry"
  name: "Quarkus CXF OpenTelemetry"
  nameSource: "EXTENSION_METADATA"
  detected: true
elements:
  io.quarkiverse.cxf.opentelemetry.CxfOpenTelemetryConfig.otel:
    description: "Global OpenTelemetry configuration."
  io.quarkiverse.cxf.opentelemetry.CxfOpenTelemetryConfig.endpoints:
    description: "Endpoint configurations."
  io.quarkiverse.cxf.opentelemetry.CxfOpenTelemetryConfig.clients:
    description: "Client configurations."
  io.quarkiverse.cxf.opentelemetry.CxfOpenTelemetryConfig.EndpointsConfig.otel:
    description: "OpenTelemetry related service endpoint configuration."
  io.quarkiverse.cxf.opentelemetry.CxfOpenTelemetryConfig.GlobalOtelConfig.enabledFor:
    description: "Specifies whether the OpenTelemetry tracing will be enabled for\
      \ clients, services, both or none. This global setting\ncan be overridden per\
      \ client or service endpoint using the `quarkus.cxf.client.\"client-name\".otel.enabled`\
      \ or\n`quarkus.cxf.endpoint.\"/endpoint-path\".otel.enabled` option respectively."
    since: "2.7.0"
  io.quarkiverse.cxf.opentelemetry.CxfOpenTelemetryConfig.ClientsConfig.otel:
    description: "OpenTelemetry related client configuration"
```

Expected: the file should contain an element for `io.quarkiverse.cxf.opentelemetry.CxfOpenTelemetryConfig.ClientsConfig.ClientConfig.enabled` 

Possible solution: I guess there is some sort of `else if (resolvedType.isMap())` with proper handling of the map value type missing around here: 

https://github.com/quarkusio/quarkus/tree/7bbbfe265104b0ead2bb04e049903e9be0cca4c0/core/processor/src/main/java/io/quarkus/annotation/processor/documentation/config/scanner/ConfigAnnotationScanner.java#L231-L246
